Enhancing law enforcement response to COVID-19 in Jordan

description.narrative:
I. Annual Progress : In May 2020, a contract was signed between the embassy of the kingdom of the Netherlands in Jordan and Penal Reform International to implement a project titled “Enhancing law enforcement response to COVID-19 in Jordan". The project worked during its six months period on promoting safe access to justice during the pandemic, including individuals who come in contact with the law enforcement and police officers, inmates, juveniles, children accompanying their mothers in jails. The project has succeeded in protecting the rights of individuals who come in contact with the law, either because they committed a crime or because they want to report a crime, or had the need to visit police stations, or courts or other judicial institutions for any reason. The project targeted all the police stations, including the pre-trail hosting cells, as those cells are small, don’t have proper ventilation, and in most cases are overcrowded, and lack hygiene, in addition to the 13 Juvenile police stations. Police officers who interact daily with the individuals who come in contact with the law were targeted to reduce the risk of being infected, and transferring the infection to their families. The same apply to the community police who was in need to interact with the community, responding to the Jordanian community needs during the lock down. Penal Reform International during the project has adopted a customized strategy to respond to the special needs of each category within the security system including the psychological, and physical needs, especially the most vulnerable segment of women, children accompanying their moms in prisons, juveniles. The project was able to provide a better health and justice solutions throughout the community. All which has resulted in a better functioning of the rule of the law system, and enhance the trust of individuals, and citizens in the police measures of maintaining health and safety. The project direct beneficiaries are: The Public Security Directorate officers, including Juvenile police department, community police, individuals who comes in contact with the law and visit police stations, juveniles and children who comes with contact with the law and visit Juvenile police stations, male and female prisoners and children accompanying their mothers. Covid-19 pandemic has globally affected all countries and sectors since November 2019, Jordan and the security sector is part of this global pandemic, all the population which is in a direct interaction with the system-(The Public Security Directorate officers, including Juvenile police department, community police, individuals who come in contact with the law and visit the police stations, in addition to juveniles and children who visit Juvenile police stations, and male and female prisoners and children accompanying their mothers, were at risk of being infected by the virus. In Jordan there are 111 police station scattered across over the kingdom with an average of 84,000 visitors per month, also 17 prison institutions, with a total capacity of 13,352, and hold around 18,000 prisoners up till 20th of March 2020. The prisons were overcrowded, and the project activities came to support the national efforts, including supporting the initiative of the Judicial Council to take a decision of reducing overcrowding in prisons as an urgent response to reduce the rate of incarcerated personnel per prison to reduce the rate of spread of infections among inmates, and prison staff., the project also supported the prison department initiative to protect inmates and build an independence vis a vis the response to the pandemic , and create a production chain of safety gates. On 24th of March 2020 the Judicial Council took a decision of an immediate release for all prisoners with a judgment less than 2 years and replacing the imprisonment with a ban on travel, including drug offenders. In addition to decision of not detaining any financial related crimes that amounts to less than (140,000 USD), replacing that with a ban on travel, and released all prisoners that fall under the same category of crime from prisons with a ban on travel.
As a result, for these measures around 6000 prisoners were released from prisons to reduce the prison population from 18,000 to 12,642 prisoners according to official statistics of Correctional and Rehabilitation Centers (CRCs) on the 6th of April 2020. Additionally, CRCs took a set of preventive measures inside the prisons that included allocating one prison only for new prisoners who will be detained all over Jordan (Al-Balqa prison). In an attempt to reduce the risk of infection spread which might be coming with new prisoners coming from outside the prisons. So, no new prisoners will be entering any of the prisons facilities that already had prisoners before, until they are quarantined for some time in Al-Balqa prison first. This will enable the CRCs to reduce the risk of infection spread that might come from outside the prisons, and maintain the health of inmates, prison staff, and their families at homes.

IV. Risks and bottlenecks Risks related to context: Governmental well and priorities: PRI has ensured continuous communication channels with the PSD high officials which enabled a smooth implementation of the project activities utilizing mutual efforts and resources, accordingly all the interventions were implemented in agreement with the PSD priorities and the governmental regulations related to the defence orders. Risks related to programming: Lack of social acceptance for behavioural change and responding for the health preventive measures by the prisoners or their relatives: PRI have designed the awareness campaigns and advocacy activities with relevance to the targeted audience needs and comprehension levels of the main preventatives measures regarding COVID-19, accordingly the awareness posters were designed with a very simple language along illustrative symbols of the actions to be taken. Also, women and children were not excluded as the design of the posters was gender sensitive, along a special design made for the children. Risks related to the organization: Anti-fraud and anti-corruption policy within the organization: PRI has adopted its’ bribery and an anti-corruption policy, including its’ various financial procedures and controls, during the implementation of the project activities, PRI has used its’ legal ways of providing financing to the partners in Jordan. Along to, ensuring the on-going monitoring mechanism, of resources and expenditures via budget financial controls. Organization structure and culture: Penal Reform International is an international non-governmental organization working on penal and criminal justice reform worldwide. PRI has regional offices and programmers in the Middle East and North Africa, Central and Eastern Europe, Central Asia and the South Caucasus. Also, PRI work with partner organizations in other parts of Africa and, using a variety of approaches, on penal reform issues in Asia, North and Latin America and the Caribbean. PRI has Consultative Status with the United Nations (ECOSOC) and the Council of Europe, and Observer Status with the African Committee on the Right and Welfare of the Child, the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights, and the Inter-Parliamentary Union. PRI is also a registered civil society organization with the Organization of American States (OAS).PRI works with governments, and civil society to improve conditions of detention. PRI promotes greater transparency and accountability in the criminal justice and penal systems through holistic policy development and legal reform, including encouraging reform processes aimed at humanising juvenile justice, detention conditions and implementing rehabilitation programmes, the development and implementation of international human rights instruments in relation to law enforcement and prison conditions, the elimination of unfair and unethical discrimination in all penal measures. PRI’s work involves cooperation and collaboration with governments, other official authorities and non-governmental partners, which helps PRI, maintains impartiality, sustainability and builds trust with all of its partners. PRI covers the Middle East and North Africa region from its Jordan office. It has been working in this region for 14 years now, covering 13 countries.
Monitoring, evaluation and management quality: PRI has developed a project monitoring, evaluation and learning (MEL) system to track the results of the project. The MEL system has included: A theory of change which shows the logical linkages and assumptions between the goal, results, outputs and activities. A monitoring framework with results statements, milestones, targets and identified data collection sources. The project team have systematically collect data to track the indicators at outcome and output level utilizing various data collection tools and reporting templates.
Financial and administrative management: As an international NGO with 30 years of history, PRI has well-established financial management mechanisms for its programmatic activity. In the first instance, a day-to-day financial administration for the project has be undertaken by the MENA finance manager, with the oversight of the Project Manager. The MENA finance manager has reported on a monthly basis to the Regional Director and Financial Director in London, who oversees the whole financial transactions of the MENA office. Monthly reports on the financial performance of the project has been submitted to PRI home office. These are checked against financial projections which are agreed between the London and Regional Offices at the commencement of any programme. Major changes to the spending of the project are discussed between the Financial Managers and the Regional Director.
V. Sustainability:
Self-sufficiency approach and positive investment in the prisoners was utilized during the phases of the current project, which guarantees sustainability, as the relation between PRI, the PSD and CRC is not supplier to consumer relationship rather a supplier to supplier relationship, which means that PRI is not acting as a direct provider of technical services and logistical support for a final consumer institution, but rather for an institution which will act as a supplier of new products. And this is guaranteed, through the vocational and reintegration programs prompted inside the prisons. From that time onward ,the prisoners started manufacturing the needed Sterilization Machines, to be used for preventing the spread of COVID-19 in all the police stations and juvenile police department and CRCs all across Jordan.
Visibility PRI has worked during the implementation of the project on guaranteeing the visibility of the donor, through continuous communication and coordination between the project manager and the embassy staff prior publishing or printing or distributing any materials to the public, either in a tangible and/or electronic format, and ensuring a proper branding for the kingdom of Netherlands logo per the instructions and regulations embedded by the embassy. This has covered the publications produced during the project timeline-(ex. The health protocol, Awareness Posters), and the digital outreach (ex. PRI official Facebook page, local News channels, Radio Broadcasting), as well as the advocacy activities through the documentary produced in partnership with the PSD aiming at communicating the shared results and illustrating the impact of the contributions. In addition, all tangible aids provided for the PSD and CRCs were properly branded with the logo of the embassy including the sanitation gates, face masks and gloves packages, gender sensitive products packages, sanitizing products packages, COVID-19 medical apron packages.

The project was implemented within the planned timeline, based on MoU’s and field inspection and follow up. PRI provided a rapid support for the Public Security Directorate and the Correctional and Rehabilitation Centers including Women Correctional and Rehabilitation Centers, along with the Juvenile police department to response to COVID -19 pandemic. The project was able to achieve the following outcomes and outputs as follows:
Outcome No. 1: New behavioral and attitudinal practices adopted within the security system (represented mainly within the CRC and PSD, juvenile’s department boundaries) for responding to the COVID-19. PRI has developed a guideline which was adopted by the PSD, and the CRCs, including preventive measures in line with the WHO standards, to ensure safety of the police staff, individuals who come in contact with the law and the community in general. The PSD took new measures to respond to COVID-19 that were discussed in different meetings with PRI which included: • Family visits suspended in order to reduce the dangers of the contact with the contaminated outside world. • Virtual courts, which allowed an online adjudication of cases. • Immediate release of inmates with cases adjudicated up to two years, replacing it with a ban on travel, as an effort to end overcrowding. • Appointing Al-Balqa prison to be the only prison for admitting new prisoners, keeping them for a minimum of two weeks, to ensure that they are negative COVID-19 cases prior transferring them into other prisons across the kingdom.
Outcome No. 2: Self-sufficiency approach through positively involving the prisoners adopted within the security system for securing the logistical and supply needs in emerging crisis. The following outcome was achieved through utilizing the principle of give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime’, involving the prisoners in manufacturing sanitization gates at Al-Swaqa prison, then distributing them at all main entrances of police stations, juveniles police departments and CRCs reaching 94.3% of self-sufficiency of those gates for the security sector as a whole. The experience of involving the inmates in the production process of the sanitation gates has raised their confidence level, as they contributed in the national efforts towards combating the pandemic. As the total number of police stations (111), juvenile police centers (13), and prisons (17) all across Jordan equaling 141., Producing 133 sanitation entrance gates, contributed to 94% of the total PSD needs. Outcome No. 3: Trust is enhanced, and made stronger due to the measures taken by the PSD to sustain access to safe justice and protect right to health and reach out to the community through community policing with positive messages, raising awareness of the public, and defending the public right to health. The Trust between the Jordanian society and the PSD has been enhanced, as a result of a set of activities delivered by PRI jointly with PSD which was promoted through national TV and social media platforms, radio broadcasting .The trust gained by the Jordanian citizens can be demonstrated in two main proxy indicators: -The number of people that accessed the police stations has increased, or was not affected by the pandemic, in comparison with the same period of the previous year, which shows that the Jordanian community has the trust to go to the police stations when they need to get a service or have to report for a crime to those centres. In the first three months of the lockdown and the domestic abuse crime rate increased by 33%, compared to the same time the year before. The stress level increased with a 1685 new domestic abuse cases made in the first three months of the lockdown including physical, sexual, and physiological abuses which caused the reported cases to increase at the police stations. .The citizens felt safe reporting their complains to the nearest police station to their homes, as they trust the justice system, and the PSD in protecting their right.
In addition, the evaluation done with the direct beneficiaries from the One-Body initiative, shows the enhancement of the trust as the following statistics prove:
According to a survey done with the direct beneficiaries of the 141 food parcels, 130 (92%) went to the police station to collect the parcels. Nine (6%) had the parcel delivered to their houses. 2% did not respond to the question. Of the 130 that went to the police station, seven had already been to the station before. 123 (95%) had never been to the police station before (36 or 29% Jordanians; 87 or 71% Syrians). One respondent specifically mentioned that due to living with physical handicap they were not able to go to the police station to collect the parcel, and therefore had it delivered.
Almost all (97%) of the respondents reported feeling "completely safe" when receiving the food parcel. 93% were "completely satisfied" with the distribution process. The 6% who were not satisfied did not provide a reason, although there were some remarks regarding the lack of shade at the distribution site or disorganised distributions at first stages. When asked "Has your perception of the police been impacted?" 94% reported it had for the better, 6% reported no change and 1% for the worse.
Outputs: Output 1.1: PRI managed to develop an educational campaign through creating awareness posters which promotes in easy language with photos the protective and preventive measures that should be taken and followed by the staff and the individuals who visited the police stations . 2000 posters were designed, printed out and distributed among all police stations including the Juvenile departments across the Kingdom. 1400 posters were created targeting adults, and 600 child friendly poster taking into consideration a gender sensitive language in the design of the poster’s instructions and precautions measures (See Annex. No. 1 & 2)
Output 1.2: PRI in cooperation with the public security directorate developed a practical guideline on the response to COVID-19 at the police station’s level, based on the International Standards for Human Rights, WHO, OHCHR health instructions, and Child Rights Committee (CRC) and in line with the Jordanian laws and regulations. .. This guideline serves as a directive tool for the daily procedures that should be undertaken by the police station officers, including topics related to how to mitigate the potential risks resulting from COVID-19 to staff and individuals who come in contact with the law, in addition to preventative measures when dealing with COVID-19, starting at the external gates of the institutions. (See Annex No. 3)
Output 2.1: During the project lifetime PRI supported the PSD in creating a vocational training production line to produce the sanitation gates inside AL-Swaqa prison. PRI coordinated with PSD the production of the sanitation gates inside the prison involving the inmates as part of supporting their rehabilitation, part of the national efforts taken by the government to fight COVID-19.
A capacity building workshop on the vocational programme for the benefit of 45 prisoners was organised at the beginning of the project aiming at teaching the prisoners how to produce the gates. 133 sanitation entrance gates produced and used at the entrance of 111 police station, 13 juvenile police stations, and prisons in Jordan including the female prisons. To make sure that the workshop is sanitized properly and there is no risk for COVID-19 infection PRI provided the safety equipment for everyone involved, including special masks, safety gears, gloves that the prisoners will be wearing during the production phases of the gates
Output 2.2: To make sure that individuals who come in contact with the law have the minima level of protection when they enter stations, and that police officers have the same level of protection and don’t fear the risk of spreading the infection to their families while they are on duty, PRI provided Hygienic supplies for the PSD including 175,800 disposable pairs of gloves, 46,000 reusable face masks, and 487,450 surgical face masks for the benefit of 13,320 officers working at 111 police stations, in addition to 420 officers working with Juveniles at 13 police stations and over 300,000 individuals who visited the police stations during the life of project. In addition PRI run a sanitation campaign inside all police stations in Jordan, and juvenile police stations, including at the pre-trial stage cells, which the detainees stay in during the investigation phases. The launch took place in September with the participation of the representative of the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherland. (See Annex No. 4)
Output 2.3: PRI launched the project in May 2020 in the presence of her excellency the ambassador of Netherlands in Jordan who provided 450 women prisoners with hygienic materials in order to respond to their specific needs and protect their rights to health. 400 pack of antibacterial wipes, 6750 pack of pads and 3270 soap bars were distributed. (See Annex No. 5)
Output 3.1: PRI partnered with Siren to ensure that the role of Community police will still be active during the lockdown across the country. PRI provided Siren with 100,000 disposable sanitized gloves and 10,000 reusable face mask which were distributed to the community police to guarantee that the safety measures are maintained during the distribution of food parcels for families who are in need in North Amman within the One Body Community Initiative, Shoulder to Shoulder Project implemented by Siren.
Output 3.2: PRI in collaboration with the PSD produced a five minutes documentary showing the main measures, and practices made by the Public Security Directorate PSD and the Correctional, & Rehabilitation Centers CRCs, in responding to COVID-19 and the main lessons learnt during the process. The broadcast was published among different media channels, official TV, and social media platforms as part of the project promotion, which in return increased the trust of the Jordanian community of the PSD measures taken to sustain access to justice and protect individual’s right to health. This guaranteed the visibility of the Dutch government contribution, and support to Jordanian population in fighting COVID-19. (See Annex No. 6)
Output 3.3: PRI organized a session with key personnel from the public security directorate, and some prisoners and other representatives of international NGOs, and prison directorate, during which, the main project outcomes were presented including the main measures taken to respond for COVID-19 in Jordan within the security eco-system, and how those measures have contributed to enhancing access to justice and law enforcement rule in protecting the right to health during quarantine.

title.narrative: DEC COVID: Immediate humanitarian assistance to most affected and vulnerable children, adolescent boys and girls and their caregivers in Ukhiya Upazila

description.narrative:
This project will remain consistent with Plan International’s global mission to emphasize the needs of women and girls. This project will primarily focus on the host community needs and will be complementary to the existing projects in the camp.
• To address child protection concerns, especially for girls and adolescent women Community Based Child Protection (CBCP) committee members, with the support of community volunteers and mentors, will conduct orientation for child and youth safe space management, training on protective and gender-responsive psychosocial support Child protection, Psychological First Aid (PFA), gender equality, SGBV, SRHR for volunteers, PSHEA and Safeguarding and refresher training on safeguarding to 1200 adolescent boys and girls. • Provide age appropriate and gender responsive support for the 1200 children and adolescents (5-9 year, 10-13 year and 14-17 year). • To reduce the further risk of infection and better prepare the community to be able to move around more safely this project will distribute reusable safety face masks to 55,000 beneficiaries in Camp 1E and in two host communities unions Raja Palong and Palong Khali. • Distribute 600 hygiene kits to 200 adolescent girls and boys in Raja Palong and 400 girls and boys in Palong Khali in Ukhiya sub-district. • Provide 448 host community households with unconditional cash transfers (Minimum Emergency Basket grant) for two months. • COVID-19 awareness messaging including adhesive stickers and poster

Closing Gaps: Strengthening Urban Resilience through Protection and Inclusion Strategies in the Caribbean

description.narrative:
This proposal is aimed at strengthening the capacities of bi-national DRR National Prevention, Mitigation and Response bodies in Cuba and Dominican Republic to permanently learn and collaborate, and to engage in advocacy work towards DRR regional bodies. A series of gaps were identified in the needs assessment, including the lack of institutionalization of key risk management tools and processes, information management during all the phases of the disaster, and coordination between the local, national, bi-national and regional levels. With this in mind, an intervention has been designed that is geared at consolidating local risk management capacities in the municipalities of Baracoa and San Antonio del Sur in Cuba, the institutionalization of tools in the National Prevention, Mitigation and Response Systems in the Dominican Republic and Cuba as well as the establishment of coordination mechanisms between both countries, the development of strategic alliances with CDEMA and CEPREDENAC and advocacy in regional consensus-building spaces. The proposed work will be closely coordinated with other risk management and development initiatives and will strive to develop sustainable risk management agendas in both countries. Direct beneficiaries: 11607 individuals and 82 organizations
Since March 2020 has pivoted and modified for COVID-19 response.

title.narrative: Providing protective, inclusive, safe and continued quality education for Covid-19 and conflict affected children in NE Nigeria
Provision of life saving assistance to children under five years of age suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) amid the COVID-19 Pandemic in Borno and Yobe state, North east Nigeria

description.narrative: Plan International Nigeria will implement a 12-month project focusing on improving access and coverage of quality lifesaving nutrition services integrated with psychosocial support in Borno and Yobe states. The project will also strengthen the capacity of government healthcare providers in Stabilization Centers (SC) ensuring the continuity and sustainability of these vital services amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The project will treat Complicated SAM cases in SCs with formula milk (F100 & F75), daily assess and follow up on the medical condition of the children and take their anthropometric measurement. The project will further provide stimulation, psychosocial support and counselling services, and promote Optimal IYCF-E (Infant and Young Child Feeding in Emergencies) practices. We will support nutrition partners implementing in the community through active case finding/screening, identifying SAM with medical complication at Out Patient therapeutic Program (OTP) centres & refer treated Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) cases from SC to OTP and vis-versa in Kaga, Konduga, Mafa, Hawul, and Chibok Local Government Areas (LGAs) in Borno state and Bade LGA of Yobe state. The proposed project will reach a total of 2501 children (1276 girls &1225 boys) under five-years of age in 6 (six) decentralized SCs in Borno and Yobe state. The proposed activities will strengthen the management of acute malnutrition in Borno and Yobe state by providing inpatient management of SAM in hospitals (SC sites) and also will establish new SC and strengthening the existing SC to provide service for IDP/host communities. In the course of its implementation, the project shall integrate gender responsive messaging in its community engagement processes, share information, encourage discussions and address gender issues that impact optimal IYCF. Given that prevailing gender roles often discourage men from participating in traditionally perceived care roles, the project shall implement a male engagement strategy that will improve male participation and support in positive IYCF practices at household and community levels. In addition, the project will raise awareness on COVID-19 mode of transmission and gender responsive and inclusive prevention strategies. The project will also provide technical and logistical support and strengthen the supportive supervision and monitoring system in the LGAs. The project will focus on supporting the most vulnerable population groups, specifically children under five years of age, caretakers of SAM children, caretakers of SAM children who are living with disabilities and other vulnerable groups. Plan International will integrate management of complicated SAM cases into existing health services in each general hospital and in the LGA health system using State Primary Health Care and Development Agency (SPHCDA) and hospital staff in all targeted LGAs. At project start-up, Plan International Nigeria will prioritize identifying Complicated SAM cases to facilitate access to life-saving services for children under five years of age and to enable management of these SAM cases in collaboration with SPHCDA and hospital board Management staff. We will strengthen the capacity of the government service providers as well as parents, guardians and care takers to prevent malnutrition and respond to the treatment of complicated SAM cases and we will work closely with government and partners working in each LGA. The project will strengthen accountability to beneficiaries through the establishment and strengthening of an inclusive and appropriate community and facility -based complaints and feedback mechanism that will allow women, girls, men, and boys to safely report concerns of the emergency nutrition response in their respective Hospital. The project also will ensure gender sensitive monitoring and evaluation is undertaken by disaggregating all data by sex, age, disability and creating complimentary qualitative and quantitative indicators.

title.narrative: NERF: Resilience Plus

description.narrative:
The “Resilience Plus” programme led by consortium partners Mercy Corps and Plan International aims to reach approximately 2660 people (5330 HHs) across Provinces 1, 2, 5 and 7. The goal of the programme is to ensure COVID-19-related resilience of vulnerable households is strengthened through the value voucher distribution and integrated access to improve to protection services and linkages to safety nets.
Issues of protection and inclusion will be mainstreamed through the project, it includes key activities under Objective 2. Consortium teams will be trained on protection, inclusion, and safeguarding, with consortium members responsible for flowing down this content to local partners. The programme will also engage with the government at multiple levels to advocate for protection and inclusion issues. This will include supporting the local government to activate and implement the protection coordination mechanism. The programme will undertake service mapping and awareness-raising of available services, to ensure people at risk of protection issues have access to preventive and response services for issues like SGBV, and providing emergency referral services for those vulnerable to, or survivors of, VAWG, including SGBV.
Gender is a central compounding disadvantage, so the program will mainstream gender through the project and strive to incorporate gender minimum standards, and incorporate analysis on gender dynamics and decision making at the household level during the needs assessment and PDM, to ensure the programme is gender sensitive. The consortium will ensure attention to gender issues in HR, recruitment, and consortium staff orientation will be a priority. The consortium’s Steering Committee will regularly review gender and inclusion disaggregated data, to ensure responsive programming.

title.narrative: Girls Education Challenge (GEC) - Transition

description.narrative: The Girls’ Access To Education – Girls’ Education Challenge (GATE-GEC) programme is a 4-year UK Aid-funded initiative in Sierra Leone to increase the education opportunities for marginalised girls and children with disabilities. GATE-GEC works across six districts in Sierra Leone and consists of a consortium of four organisations that include Plan International, Action Aid, Humanity & Inclusion and The Open University. As a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, GATE-GEC has redesigned the project to address the immediate education, health and well-being needs among girls and other marginalised groups. Our approach responds to a need for a rapid response to the access, retention and safeguarding issues now faced by marginalised girls and children with disabilities in SL. Our revised strategy is comprised of three activity strands that include Teaching and Learning, Access and Retention and Psychosocial Support Interventions. The three strands of activity work together to ensure girls and children with disabilities are supported to safely return and stay in school amid the Covid-19 crisis. The approach works at a national, regional and local level to support the ongoing educational development, health and wellbeing of girls and children with disabilities within school and community contexts.

title.narrative: Monitoring Changes in the Situation of Older Persons in Asia-Pacific in Light of Covid-19

description.narrative: The Covid-19 pandemic and its consequences pose significant threats to the wellbeing and dignity of older persons across the Asia-Pacific region. The pandemic will have far-reaching and long-lasting impacts in unpredictable ways. Monitoring the impacts of Covid-19 on older persons is therefore essential to inform policy makers and the broader society in order to ensure responses are inclusive of older persons. As ageing is an important part of UNFPA's mandate, it will be critical for UNFPA to keep abreast of the fast-moving developments in coming months. HelpAge therefore proposes to reallocate its approved 2020 budget for the assignment as outlined in this Concept Note, as the Asia-Pacific Regional Conference cannot be held as planned this year. The findings will inform the development of the next Asia-Pacific Regional Conference, which will be rescheduled for 2021.

To broadly monitor, document, analyze and share how the situation of older people in Asia changes in 2020 as a result of Covid-19, in order to inform programmatic responses and policy advice, post-pandemic.

title.narrative: Video animation on homecare for older people: COVID 19

description.narrative: It is now known that older persons (especially the older old) face a much higher risk of dying from COVID-19 than the general population, as do those with underlying health conditions. An early study from China's National Health Commission suggested that about 80 per cent of people who died from the virus in China were over the age of 60, and 75 per cent had pre-existing conditions. We find similar patterns in European countries. Older people who are dependent on carers and living in care homes are far more at risk as they can only have limited isolation and are in close contact with care providers on a daily basis. Care homes have become hotbeds for COVID-19 infections in many parts of the world. Asia is expecting to follow the similar trends. There are more than 2,000 care homes, both institutional and informal in South East Asia. In South Asia, India alone has around 40,000 care homes in the country. Another group of older people who need special care is those living in their community and receiving home and social care from community volunteers. Providing information and guidelines to centarl governments or throough websites is important but insufficient. The messages have to reach all echelons of the care suystems. So, simple presentation of the topic and smart dissemination are crucial. HelpAge plans to develop two video animation to provide simple, clear guidelines to care homes and community care in the context of COVID-19.
To provide simple and clear guidelines for home-based care organisers and providers at community levels, preventing infection and maintaining carers and cared safe
To provide simple and clear guidelines on how to protect older people in care homes, preventing infection and maintaining carers and cared safe

title.narrative: Integrated Humanitarian Response to the Needs of the COVID-19 Affected Rohingya Older Women and Men

description.narrative:
Since October 2017, HelpAge has been implementing an Integrated Humanitarian Response Programme amongst the 21,000 older women and men of Forcefully Displaced Myanmar Nationals (FDMN) in the 06 makeshift camps – 8E, 11, 12, 13, 15 and 18 and in Palongkhali union in the adjacent Host Community (HC) of Ukhiya sub-district, Cox's Bazar district, Bangladesh. HelpAge is providing humanitarian support to FDMN men and women aged 50+ and men and women aged 60+ in the HC. Through this programme, HAI are providing geriatric healthcare, physiotherapeutic services, psycho-social counselling, age and disability friendly WaSH, protection, nutrition, economic self-reliance, prevention & care of COVID-19 as well as technical support to other humanitarian actors and advocacy for age and disability inclusive humanitarian responses for older people in the Rohingya response.
For this project, HelpAge and local partners Resource Integration Centre (RIC) and Young Power for Social Action (YPSA) are proposing to extend activities to camps 14, 19 and to HCs in the adjacent area - Joarinala union in Ramu Sub-district. This response will reach 6,000 older women and men, again with a focus on FDMN aged 50+ and HCs aged 60+.

title.narrative: Enhancing the emergency COVID-19 response through improving access to basic needs and protection services for the most vulnerable and marginalised older women and men with and without disabilities during the winter months in 4 governorates of Jordan.

description.narrative: The proposed 4-month emergency response project aims at improving access to basic needs and protection services for the most vulnerable and marginalised older women and men with and without disabilities during the winter months and to help them cope with the secondary impacts of COVID-19, in Amman, Mafraq, Zarqa, and Irbid. The project will provide cash assistance to support 800 of the most vulnerable older people (70% of older women) and their family members in meeting their basic needs, in particular food, medication for chronic disease as well as heating costs for the winter months. Through cash assistance, the project will help mitigate the negative impact of the pandemic. Protection will be mainstreamed throughout the project implementation to ensure safe and meaningful access to cash for older people, while preserving their dignity. In addition, the project will put a special focus on PSEA and age and gender based violence; it will ensure that all staff and volunteers involved in the project and members of target communities are well aware of PSEA and age and gender-based violence, as well as safeguarding concerns, and how reports can be made safely. At least 50 staff and volunteers will be trained on PSEA and safeguarding. 1000 community members, including 800 older men and women (70% of women), will receive direct information related to PSEA, age and gender-based violence, and safeguarding. HelpAge will promote the use of the referral mechanism for survivors of SEA and age and genderbased violence. Referrals to UNHCR focal points for PSEA, in Irbid and Mafraq, or to other specialised agencies when they exist in the local area, will be supported by the project when needed. All components of the project will adhere to the humanitarian principles and the core humanitarian standards. This project meets the goals and standards of the allocation, the COVID-19 and the Global HRP by targeting one of the most vulnerable and neglected groups, older men and women. The project is designed around the HRP strategic priority: This project will create synergies with the local organizations, communities, and strengthen prevention and PSEA awareness in response to the JRP. It will also highlight the lessons learnt and advocate for the inclusion of older men and women with and without disabilities in various humanitarian programmes, mainstreaming gender and PSEA. This project will address the gaps in services regarding older men and women and highlight the needs. This advocacy work will be throughout the duration of the project and beyond and will be shared with the various clusters (protection, basic needs), working groups and the Jordan INGO forum.

title.narrative: Rapid humanitarian response to impacts of the COVID-19 crisis on Older Persons, People with Disabilities, and Venezuelan Caminantes, returnees and homeless in La Guajira, North Santander and Santander, Colombia

description.narrative:
The project is designed to provide essential goods and services to 6850 critically vulnerable persons (Older Persons, People with Disabilities, and Venezuelan Caminantes, returnees and homeless) who are assessed as highly susceptible to the COVID-19 and its social and economic impacts. The project will be implemented within 3 Departments of Colombia (La Guajira, North Santander and Santander) at a critical time of the expected peak of the virus in the country. Specifically, the Consortium of HelpAge, HI and SI will seek to conduct the following:
La Guajira: HelpAge and HI will target the specifically vulnerable populations of Older People, Persons with Disabilities and Care Workers, who are assessed as the most at risk populations in La Guajira in regards to the risk of contracting the virus, the health risks of the having the virus, and the related social and economic impacts. To do so, HelpAge will carry out preventive Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) measures (e.g. Hygiene Kit distribution of sanitizers, soap, protective gear, etc.); provide water and water storage tanks to families within the informal settlements that have older people or persons with disabilities; provide awareness sessions for local implementing staff, carers, community leaders and public in general on how to prevent and assist these at-risk population during the COVID-19 humanitarian response; conduct a public health campaign with relevant, friendly and accessible material to guarantee that these populations are informed about the risks and how to be safe; and support the Mental and Psychosocial Health of this target population at this critical time. Finally, unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers will be implemented through the local banking network to migrants and members of host communities at risk (older people, families with a person with disabilities, people with chronic illness). This cash should enable 80 of the most at-risk households to cover their basic needs for 2 months while access to work is reduced and the cost of the household basket has increased.
North Santander and Santander: SI intends to provide basic food security and/or hygiene materials in North Santander and Santander, for highly vulnerable Venezuelans in Bucaramanga, Pamplona and on the migrant route to the Venezuelan border. To do so, SI will provide food security to homeless or evicted persons who are currently placed in emergency COVID-19 refuges (750 individuals); provide essential food and hygiene items to highly vulnerable households in Pamplona and Bucaramanga who have been assessed as specifically impacted by the health, social or economic impacts of the crisis (800 households); and provide mobile food and hygiene items to families starting the long return journey to the Venezuelan border (320 families). This is in response to the assessed critical needs in key areas within the department, and that providing these in-kind items will fill these critical needs for at least 1 month (for the Venezuelans and Colombians individuals and households) and at least 48 hours for the Venezuelan returnees, especially because of the significant obstacles in affordability and access due to the COVID-19 crisis.
The Consortium will mitigate harm and loss by ensuring strong initial assessments and targeting, specific and rationalistic designs of the planned activities, clear alignment to both international and national guidelines and policies (e.g., Sphere Standards, Government guidelines on COVID-19 protocols), and adherence to internal Standard Operating Procedures and policies (e.g. Security Protocols, use of PPE, distribution guidelines).

title.narrative: New Priorities for Health Care Needs and Livelihoods (including COVID-19 responses).

description.narrative: Ensuring older people are active, they feel less lonely and isolated and are able to cope with daily challenges
Ensuring older people are in the best possible physical health

The unique direct participants of the project are estimated to be 445 vulnerable older persons (about 50 men and 395 women) in 5 target communities who experience lack of food or income security or have limited access to healthcare. The indirect project participants, will primarily be household members or dependents such as partners, children or grandchildren of direct participants. The wider population of older people living in five target communities will also be reached. An estimated total population in five project communities is about 12981 persons of which 2168 are population of older people – 6601 women and 2168 are men.

This programme aims to maximize the potential of older women and men in five communities of Moldova to improve their health, well-being, social participation and communication. It will provide support to the vulnerable older women and men to increase their access to healthcare and manage their chronic health conditions, with a focus on hypertension, diabetes with support of volunteers from their peers. These volunteers support the needs of vulnerable older women and men that will be identified through the baseline survey inbuilt in the project They are trained to measure blood pressure and to monitor overall health status, including seasonal diseases, during home-care visits to older people with limited mobility. As a new element, the project will support development of HealthCare Peer Support Groups, formed from more active older people, who will meet together and exchange experiences in managing their own health. The volunteers also do referrals of urgent cases to the family doctors for those who are immobile, and will facilitate meetings of the Peer Group with presentations from different medical experts in the area of needs identified by the Peer Groups. To further increase access to healthcare, the volunteers will also facilitate roll-out of medical express tests in five communities across Moldova with support of the Ministry of Health and local Medical Centres. Activities on Active Ageing will be run - physical exercises and some sports competitions - hat will focus on social integration and participation of older people in their communities based on their needs in communication and social participation. A further component of the programme will enable older people with low income and poor nutrition, to develop age friendly livelihood activities that will support their food and income security. Study visits to the beneficiaries of successful livelihood activities will be organised for knowledge and experience transfer. Older people who do not qualify for the livelihood due to ill health or other functional vulnerability will be targeted through winter support food packages, home-visiting and participating in the Active Ageing activities.

title.narrative: Protecting Older People headed households from COVID-19 through community-based health systems strengthening and food security initiatives

description.narrative: The project will target 2500 households headed by older people in Bebedo, Nhamboca, Ndeja and Metochira Ressetlemnt Sites communities of Nhamatanda district and Mutua and Chinamcondo communities in Dondo district. The intervention is planned to strengthen linkage and coordination of community level structures with the health systems in the process of mitigating and responding to COVID-19 through: 1) Strengthening the capacity of older people structures that HelpAge has successfully developed in order to address the information gaps on COVID-19; promote referral linkages of suspected cases (HBCs will be linked with the formal health systems; and address isolation, psychosocial trauma and fear among older people. 2) To strengthen health system responses by influencing the National COVID-19 response to ensure issues of COVID-19 combined with other conditions are observed in the GoM response plan and fully addressed; 3) Direct support to older people who are self-isolating through food item distributions and provision of transport at the sufficient time to move to market to get supplies ahead of any quarantine as will be agreed with the government. 4) Provide HelpAge and partner staff with clear guidance on health awareness through training and capacity development sessions; and provision of PPE safety equipment gear for COVID-19.

title.narrative: Inclusive Social Protection and Livelihoods in Magway Region and Kayin State (including COVID-19 responses)

description.narrative: : Children with disabilities in rural HH have educational opportunities at the village level and all children have improved nutrition awareness.
CSOs provide access to essential social protection support to HHs with persons with disabilities (village based).
Coordination between CSOs and government social protection institutions on improved access to social protection for persons with disabilities.
Government and INGOs/CSOs have access to learning.

To improve the participation and inclusion of persons with disabilities and their households in communities and the workforce in Myanmar's Magway Region and Kayin State, this project will support their social protection and livelihoods by strengthening village-based community mechanisms, providing support for improved nutrition and educational status among children with disabilities, and strengthening government and community capacity to protect the poor. The project responds to Component 1 in the Call for Proposals (CfP) titled “Inclusion of persons with disabilities and their families in social protection and livelihood programmes” and also addresses specific elements of Component 2 under the CfP. The project will work with an estimated 500-700 direct beneficiaries and 30,000 indirect beneficiaries in 40 villages in two target townships in Magway and Region and one target township in Kayin State. In regards to COVID-19, HelpAge has repurposed some of the project activities, in consultation with the donor. This includes the distribution of information on COVID-19, pamphlets on how to stay healthy while isolated, and awareness raising on government restrictions

We estimate that a total of 700 PwDs (50% women) will be direct beneficiaries of the project over the course of 24 months. In addition, we estimate that approximately 300 household members of PwDs will directly benefit from livelihood trainings and loans. For indirect beneficiaries, the remaining members of the 40 target communities will benefit from the project through strengthened community organisations, increased community funds available for loans, and improved linkages with local skill development centres and markets for their businesses.

title.narrative: COVID-19 response for older people and people with disabilities in Myanmar

description.narrative: Following improved awareness, it is imperative to support the communities to implement preventive measures. Communities will be provided with financial support by HAI-LBG to procure materials. HAI-UK and HAI-LNG has experience in providing this kind of support, and has provided procurement training to the communities under previous projects. The installation of hand-washing stations and the provision of personal protective equipment (PPE) for home care volunteers will help the communities to limit the spread of the virus, and therefore reduce the demand on healthcare services nationwide

Global evidence reveals that older people and persons living with non-communicable diseases (NCDs) are more susceptible to develop life-threatening complications from a COVID-19 infection; hence there is a need to address their needs at the community level on a priority basis.

HelpAge will improve the awareness of the needs of older people and other vulnerable groups among the population of Myanmar regarding the COVID-19 virus. Current messaging developed for Myanmar by MoHS and WHO does not include specific mentions of these groups. Through partnerships with the MoHS and the Ministry of Social Welfare, Relief, and Resettlement, handouts, posters, and banners will be distributed nationwide – this is a replication of the distribution of information of the Package of Essential NCD (PEN) services under HelpAge's EU funded project (Specific objective 1). Following improved awareness, it is imperative to support the communities to implement preventive measures. Communities will be provided with financial support by HelpAge to procure materials. HelpAge has experience in providing this kind of support, and has provided procurement training to the communities under previous projects. The installation of hand-washing stations and the provision of personal protective equipment (PPE) for home care volunteers will help the communities to limit the spread of the virus, and therefore reduce the demand on healthcare services nationwide (Specific objective 2). Global evidences reveal that older people and persons living with non-communicable diseases (NCDs) are more susceptible to develop life-threatening complications from a COVID-19 infection; hence there is a need to address their needs at the community level on a priority basis.
HelpAge's previous EU-funded project supported the MoHS in strengthening NCD services, through 1,800 NCD clinics which are established in Rural Health Centres (RHCs). HelpAge proposes to provide these clinics with PPE, strengthening their reporting and registration system to improve the quality of their data, and streamline their referral system through a digitalised system (Specific objective 3). Lastly, the economic impact of the COVID-19 outbreak will have severe effects on the livelihoods of vulnerable people, who often rely on their families and communities to survive. HelpAge has worked with the ISHGs to set up income-generating ventures in communities that support vulnerable groups. The ISHG structure is support by their umbrella organisations, Township Network Committees (TNCs), which consist of representatives of the ISHGs and coordinate and align similar activities between the ISHGs. The TNCs have received procurement training under previous HelpAge projects, and building upon this, HelpAge will provide financial support to TNCs to procure the raw materials for ISHGs produce soap, hand sanitiser, and dispensers in communities, which can generate income during and after the project (Specific objective 4).

title.narrative: Awareness and protection of older women and men against Covid-19 in the Gaza strip

description.narrative: The project will prioritize a prevention, awareness raising and community sensitization focus, that will help mitigate the impact of a COVID-19 outbreak when it materializes. It has a particular focus on vulnerable groups of older women and men and persons with disabilities. The project involves community awareness raising activities, which will be delivered through a mix of messaging modalities, such as radio spots, mobile text messages, use of social media and distribution of leaflets. For households which include an older woman or man, who are deemed particularly vulnerable, we will deliver hygiene kits for family use, and this distribution will also be accompanied by appropriate messaging and delivery of information. In addition, we will conduct medical diabetes and hypertension tests for older people by relevant health workers. We will set up a system to ensure the maintenance of social contact with older people who might be isolated using phone calls, text messages and radio. We will also ensure that provision of awareness raising and information on COVID-19 is made accessible to different groups of people, including older people, through appropriate language, communication materials and age relevant messaging.

title.narrative: Inclusive humanitarian response for older men and women and people with disabilities affected by COVID-19 in South Sudan

description.narrative: HAI and HDC are able to influence the wider response through advocacy, campaigns, technical support and communications to ensure older people are considered and included.
Income and social protection are strengthened and older men and women and PwDs are able to cover their basic needs
Information and advice on COVID-19 is provided to older people and their carers in an inclusive and accessible way
Older men and women and people with disabilities are protected, feel safe and have full access to COVID-19 assistance

The intervention will promote an inclusive humanitarian response and community support through addressing the key needs (Food, WASH and Protection), and amplifying the voices of older persons through strengthening and expanding older persons structures to increase their inclusion in various COVID-19 and humanitarian services in Juba, South Sudan where high numbers of COVID-19 infections have been recorded.

title.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 emergency response for vulnerable older women and men in Idlib in NW Syria

description.narrative: The project prioritises prevention, awareness raising and community sensitization focus that will help mitigate the impact of a COVID-19 outbreak when it materializes. It will focus on particularly vulnerable groups such as older women and men including older people with disabilities. Community awareness raising activities will be delivered through a mix of messaging modalities, such as use of social media, distribution of paper leaflets and flyers, use of mobile ambulances to deliver messages through loudspeaker, and training of volunteers and health workers on raising awareness and protection measure regarding COVID-19 and promoting behavioural change among the potentially affected population. For households deemed particularly vulnerable, hygiene kits for family use will be delivered, and this distribution will also be accompanied by appropriate messaging and delivery of information. A system will be established to ensure the maintenance of social contact with older people who might be isolated using phone calls, text messages and radio. Provision of awareness raising and information on COVID-19 will be made accessible to different groups of people, including older people, including older people with disabilities, through appropriate language, communication materials and age- friendly and relevant messaging. Strategies will be developed to provide Psychosocial Support for older people, including those with disabilities remotely, through training of professional counsellors and delivered through radio, telephone calls or other remote mechanisms.
